column3: Ghostly white horse - appears when the locals are in danger

column5: The 'Rider on the white horse' appears when a storm threatens. Also appears on local flags.

Tatterfoal is a mischievous ghost-horse from Lincolnshire folklore, reported in older sources as haunting places like Frieston and Barton-upon-Humber. In one version collected by folklorist Mabel Peacock, the eerie creature turns out not to be supernatural at all but just a prankster in disguise, and the name later inspired a local Morris dancing group

A farmer taking a foggy shortcut along the beach at Gibraltar Point drowned in the rising tide, and ever since the frantic sound of ghostly hooves is said to thunder across the sands when the mist rolls in. The tale survives mainly as a reported haunting rather than a full narrative, with versions noting that it may date back as far as the 1700s
